Package me.wobblyyyy.edt

Class FrozenMap<K,​V>

  • java.lang.Object
    • me.wobblyyyy.edt.FrozenMap<K,​V>
  • Type Parameters:
    K - the type of object the keys belong to.
    V - the type of object the values belong to.
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    Mappable<K,​V>
    public class FrozenMap<K,​V>
extends java.lang.Object
implements Mappable<K,​V>
    An implementation of the Mappable interface designed exclusively for applications in which the contents of the map won't ever be updated.

    These values and keys cannot ever be updated. There are several other implementations of the Mappable interface that allow for these values to be changed - see DynamicMap (completely changeable) and StaticMap (only values can be changed) to learn more.

    The primary advantage to using a frozen map over a static map or a dynamic map comes from the fact that you can't accidentally change a value without getting some sort of exception.

    Author:
    Colin Robertson

    • Constructor Detail

      • FrozenMap

        public FrozenMap​(Arrayable<K> keys,
                 Arrayable<V> values)
        Create a new FrozenMap instance.

        After an instance of this map is created, the values stored in this map cannot be updated whatsoever. The map is entirely frozen, or static, or constant, or whatever you want to call it.

        If the size of the keys and values arrays are different, this constructor will throw an exception indicating that that's the case. Thankfully, there's a rather easy fix - make sure the keys and values array are the same size. Shocking, I know.

        Parameters:
        keys - all the keys that should be added to the map.
        values - all the values that should be added to the map.

      • FrozenMap

        public FrozenMap​(K[] keys,
                 V[] values)
        Create a new FrozenMap instance.

        After an instance of this map is created, the values stored in this map cannot be updated whatsoever. The map is entirely frozen, or static, or constant, or whatever you want to call it.

        If the size of the keys and values arrays are different, this constructor will throw an exception indicating that that's the case. Thankfully, there's a rather easy fix - make sure the keys and values array are the same size. Shocking, I know.

        Parameters:
        keys - all the keys that should be added to the map.
        values - all the values that should be added to the map.

      • FrozenMap

        public FrozenMap​(Arrayable<KeyValue<K,​V>> keysAndValues)
        Create a new FrozenMap instance.

        After an instance of this map is created, the values stored in this map cannot be updated whatsoever. The map is entirely frozen, or static, or constant, or whatever you want to call it.

        This constructor is rather expensive, especially when compared to the other constructors offered by the frozen map class. Just as a heads up.

        Parameters:
        keysAndValues - an array of keys and values. Each of these keys and values will be added to the frozen map's internal key and value registry.
        See Also:
        FrozenMap(Object[], Object[]), FrozenMap(Arrayable, Arrayable)

      • FrozenMap

        public FrozenMap​(KeyValue<K,​V>[] keysAndValues)
        Create a new FrozenMap instance.

        After an instance of this map is created, the values stored in this map cannot be updated whatsoever. The map is entirely frozen, or static, or constant, or whatever you want to call it.

        This constructor is rather expensive, especially when compared to the other constructors offered by the frozen map class. Just as a heads up.

        Parameters:
        keysAndValues - an array of keys and values. Each of these keys and values will be added to the frozen map's internal key and value registry.
        See Also:
        FrozenMap(Object[], Object[]), FrozenMap(Arrayable, Arrayable)

      • FrozenMap

        public FrozenMap​(Mappable<K,​V> map)
        Create a new frozen map instance by using another map as a base. This, in effect, "freezes" the newly created map. The newly created frozen map is an immortalized and frozen clone of the input map.
        Parameters:
        map - the map to use as a base. The contents of this map are copied over to the new map - no mutability issues here.

    • Method Detail

      • put

        public void put​(K key,
                V value)
        Put a given pair into the map. If the map already contains an element with the same key as the key that was inputted, replace that key's value. If the map doesn't contain the given key and the map can be expanded to include it, insert the value into the map.
        Specified by:
        put in interface Mappable<K,​V>
        Parameters:
        key - the key that the value should go under.
        value - the value the key should have.
        See Also:
        Mappable.put(KeyValue)

      • put

        public void put​(KeyValue<K,​V> keyValuePair)
        Put a given pair into the map. If the map already contains an element with the same key as the key that was inputted, replace that key's value. If the map doesn't contain the given key and the map can be expanded to include it, insert the value into the map.
        Specified by:
        put in interface Mappable<K,​V>
        Parameters:
        keyValuePair - a pair of a key and a value that should be inserted into the map. This pair contains both a key and a value.
        See Also:
        Mappable.put(Object, Object)

      • get

        public V get​(K key)
        Get the value that a specified key in the map contains.
        Specified by:
        get in interface Mappable<K,​V>
        Parameters:
        key - the key to query for.
        Returns:
        if the map contains the requested key, return the key's value. If the map doesn't contain the requested key, however, return null, indicating that the requested key could not be found.

      • getKey

        public K getKey​(V value)
        Get the key associated with a specified value.
        Specified by:
        getKey in interface Mappable<K,​V>
        Parameters:
        value - the value to search for.
        Returns:
        the first instance of a key that matches with the given value. If there are no instances of the value in the map, return null. If there are multiple instances of the requested key in the map, only return the key of the first of those indexes.

      • containsKey

        public boolean containsKey​(K key)
        Check to see if the map contains a specified key.
        Specified by:
        containsKey in interface Mappable<K,​V>
        Parameters:
        key - the key to look for.
        Returns:
        true if the map contains the requested key. Return false if the map doesn't contain the requested key.

        public boolean containsValue​(V value)

        containsValue in interface Mappable<K,​V>
        Parameters:
        value - the value to look for.
        Returns:
        true if the map contains at least one instance of the specified value, and false if it doesn't.

      • size

        public int size()
        Get the size of the map.

        This attribute is based on the quantity of entries contained in the map. Lone keys and lone values (if those exist) are not counted towards the total size of the map. In the case of map implementations that use dynamic arrays, size should still represent the total ACTIVE size, not the total allocated size.

        Specified by:
        size in interface Mappable<K,​V>
        Returns:
        the map's size.

      • clear

        public void clear()
        Clear all of the values from a map.

        Clearing a map will not reset the entire map to a new map. Rather, it will clear each of the values from the map. Each of the key elements should remain entirely intact. The value data structure should not be de-allocated - rather, it should remain allocated and ready to receive new information.

        If you're interested in "starting fresh," so to speak, you can create a new instance of the map you're using. Otherwise, this lovely clear method should get the job done fairly well.

        Specified by:
        clear in interface Mappable<K,​V>

      • itr

        public ItrPair<K,​V> itr()
        Get the map's iterator.
        Specified by:
        itr in interface Mappable<K,​V>
        Returns:
        the map's iterator. The specific implementation of the iterator is left entirely up to the implementing class, but each iterator is an implementation of the ItrPair interface, so they function near identically in practice.
